TikTok2

Registered on: ‎05-13-2013

Does anyone have a custard recipe that uses coconut milk, other nondairy milks?

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎08-15-2013 11:57 PM

I adore custards. I have a recipe for a maple custard that is so simple and to die for (eggs, milk, maple, vanilla, nutmeg). 

 

But I can't do dairy anymore. Maybe goat's milk, I have to be further tested. 

 

And the only other kind of milk that is naturally creamy and fatty in the right way is coconut, or so I think.

 

Or if you have a recipe that uses nut milk, but I can't imagine that would be very good. Maybe I'm wrong.

 

 

 

 

TikTok2

• Diabetes on both sides of my family.
• Assumed trouble metabolizing sugar as long as I can remember; migraines induced by hunger, very sleepy after meals high in carbohydrates from childhood. Learned how to avoid sugar and lots of complex carbs early on.
• Since early 2000s, "prediabetes" controlled through low carb diet and exercise, mostly walking. FBG 95-105, A1c below 6; glucose tolerance test was borderline.
• But weight drifted upwards but working on it.
• NAFLD brought under control with pravastatin.
• Metformin ER, 500 mg, started sept 2013 when A1c reached 6.5 despite diet and exercise regiment since early 2000s. A1c back down to ~6.0.

Helpful Response Given! Go to this response.

Re: Does anyone have a custard recipe that uses coconut milk, other nondairy milks?

‎08-16-2013 12:22 PM

TikTok2 wrote:

I adore custards. I have a recipe for a maple custard that is so simple and to die for (eggs, milk, maple, vanilla, nutmeg). 

 

But I can't do dairy anymore. Maybe goat's milk, I have to be further tested. 

 

And the only other kind of milk that is naturally creamy and fatty in the right way is coconut, or so I think.

 

Or if you have a recipe that uses nut milk, but I can't imagine that would be very good. Maybe I'm wrong.

 

 

 

 

I have used coconut milk in my coconut impossible pie, but have since started using whipping cream.  For the Thai Kitchen Coconut milk there are 568 calories, 24.7 g carbs per cup.  I have also used coconut milk from the regular milk aisle, near the soy and almond milks, to make the same pie.  The one I use is unsweetened So Delicious brand, with 40 calories per cup, 2 carbs, and 4.5 g fat.  To help increase the creaminess and thickness, I added an egg and more butter to the pie.  If you will add your recipe for the maple custard, I will compute the nutritional info for you.

 

Marty 

"The road to success is always under construction."
- Lily Tomlin

01/2013 - diagnosed with T2 and hypothyroidism
A1c - 7.2
04/16/2013 - A1c 6.1
07/24/2013 - A1c 5.8 (bayernow)
09/21/2013 - A1c 5.6 (bayernow)
10/10/2013 - A1c 5.7
04/30/2014 - A1c 5.5
12/10/2014 - A1c 5.4
500 mg Metformin/1 per day
Low Carb
Beginning weight - 183
08/27/2013 - 143
10/03/2013 - 141
12/05/2013 - 138
12/10/2014 - 144
Blood Pressure 12/05/2013 - 118/60
Blood Pressure 02/2014 - 106/54 (too low, medication cut to maintenance dose)
Blood Pressure 04/29/2014 - 110/65
Blood Pressure 12/10/2014 - 105/72
T2 paternal grandmother, father, two sisters, my deceased husband, and my ex husband

Thanks. When I'm home, I'll find the recipe and submit it here. I can't eat it anymore due to the milk base. And its not exactly diabetes friendly, but it was always fine, sugar wise if I just ate a little at a time.

Re: Does anyone have a custard recipe that uses coconut milk, other nondairy milks?

‎08-16-2013 07:18 PM

You could try unsweetened almond milk instead of dairy milk.  It is the eggs that give a custard most of its consistency anyways.  

 

Experiment.

 

Find a traditional custard recipe, and simply substitute unsweetened almond milk and granular splenda for the dairy ingredients and for the sugar the traditional recipe calls for.

 

I am doing a lot of experimenting with foods now that certain things have suddenly become off-limits for me.

.
Report Inappropriate Content

Re: Does anyone have a custard recipe that uses coconut milk, other nondairy milks?

‎08-16-2013 08:41 PM

nippers2 wrote:

You could try unsweetened almond milk instead of dairy milk.  It is the eggs that give a custard most of its consistency anyways.  

 

Experiment.

 

Find a traditional custard recipe, and simply substitute unsweetened almond milk and granular splenda for the dairy ingredients and for the sugar the traditional recipe calls for.

 

I am doing a lot of experimenting with foods now that certain things have suddenly become off-limits for me.

Thanks for that idea. I do use nut milk: either the unsweetened almond or the unsweetened nut blend (hazelnut, cashew, almond):

 

http://www.tastethedream.com/products/product/5299/814.php

 

on my granola, in my tea, etc.

 

Nut milk isn't great for things like yogurt, not really creamy enough, but you are right, the maple custard recipe I have is an egg custard flavored by maple. 

 

I think I will experiment, both with the nut milk, egg, maple. And the coconut milk, egg, and something else to sweeten that (maybe just buy sweetened coconut milk).....being a biochemist, I have an aversion to the artificial sweeteners....I may try agave with the lower glycemic index, or stevia, but for now I just eat a small enough amount that I'm within my carb / sugar limit. And the maple custard wouldn't be maple custard without the maple, its sooo good!

 

OK, its almost autumn, looks like I have these ideas just in time to experiment!

TikTok2

• Diabetes on both sides of my family.
• Assumed trouble metabolizing sugar as long as I can remember; migraines induced by hunger, very sleepy after meals high in carbohydrates from childhood. Learned how to avoid sugar and lots of complex carbs early on.
• Since early 2000s, "prediabetes" controlled through low carb diet and exercise, mostly walking. FBG 95-105, A1c below 6; glucose tolerance test was borderline.
